Bug.Summery: [CVS Sync View] Ignore Whitespace does not work

Lines.Line: 1. set preference to ignore whitespace
2. compare org.eclipse.jdt.doc.user/contexts_JDT.xml v20030317 with v20030318
===> lots of white space changes are reported

Bug.WithStack:
Build I20030317
1. set preference to ignore whitespace 2. compare org.eclipse.jdt.doc.user/contexts_JDT.xml v20030317 with v20030318 ===> lots of white space changes are reported
Marking bug as critical since it is almost impossible to compare the file. Ignore white space works OK in the compare editor. The state of the ignore white space check is strange in the Synchronize view drop down. You have to toggle it twice to get the actual state in sync with the one shown in the view menu.
Should fix for RC3 In the scenario that worked in the compare editor I was using two Java files.
In Dani's scenario the white space difference is that in one file the tabs got expanded into white space. No, if 'Ignore Whitespace' is on, tabs and spaces are treated correctly. The real problem is that the two versions of the file in question sometimes use the abbreviated notation <tag .... /> and sometimes the long notation <tag>...</tag>. Since the difference is at the end you can only spot it by scrolling horizontally to the right end.
Investigating the strange toggle behavior of the "ignore Whitespace" menu item in the sync view. The 'ignore white space' menu action in the Synchronize view drop down doesn't honor the default setting from the Compare preference page.
Moving to VCM. There is no longer an ignore whitespace in the synchronize view

Bug.Summery: Breakpoint installed notification sent every time breakpoint attribute changed
Bug.WithStack:
Every time a JavaBreakpoint attribute is set, IJavaBreakpointListener.breakpointInstalled() gets called for that breakpoint. There is no call to IJavaBreakpointListener.breakpointRemoved() before additional calls to breakpointInstalled(). This is a change in behaviour from Eclipse 2.1.
We have debug adapters that use hidden Java breakpoints. They use IJavaBreakpointListeners to keep track of whether the hidden Java breakpoint is installed in any VMs so that the breakpoint icon will have the checkmark on it if it is installed (similar to Java breakpoints). Due to the new behaviour, we will have to add code to all our debug adapters to do an additional check whenever breakpointInstalled() is called to see if we have already been told about this breakpoint being installed in a particular debug target. It would seem like a better solution if JDT only called breakpointInstalled() when the breakpoint is first installed in the VM, like what happened in Eclipse 2.0. CC'ing EG for RC3 approval. Darin can you confirm that this is a change in behaviour? There is a change in behavior. In 2.0, we only re-created the underlying JDI request when the breakpoint changed in a way that required the request to be re- created. In 2.1, we always re-create the request whenever a breakpoint attribute changes. This causes the "install" notification to be re-sent when the new request is created.
However, in 2.0, more than one notification would be generated if a breakpoint were installed, and then a property were changed that requires the underlying request to be recreated (such as a change in hit count).
The change is that we are creating more "double" notifications in 2.1 than 2.0. +1 Fixed. Added a cache of installed targets to JavaBreakpoint. A target is added on the first "install notification" and removed when the breakpoint is removed from the target. Install notifications are only sent when not already installed.
Added JavaBreakpointListenerTests.
Assigning to Luc & Jared for double verify. Please verify. Verified by Luc and Jared. I verified the fix in the I20030318 driver.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Every time a JavaBreakpoint attribute is set, IJavaBreakpointListener.breakpointInstalled() gets called for that breakpoint. There is no call to IJavaBreakpointListener.breakpointRemoved() before additional calls to breakpointInstalled(). This is a change in behaviour from Eclipse 2.1.
We have debug adapters that use hidden Java breakpoints. They use IJavaBreakpointListeners to keep track of whether the hidden Java breakpoint is installed in any VMs so that the breakpoint icon will have the checkmark on it if it is installed (similar to Java breakpoints). Due to the new behaviour, we will have to add code to all our debug adapters to do an additional check whenever breakpointInstalled() is called to see if we have already been told about this breakpoint being installed in a particular debug target. It would seem like a better solution if JDT only called breakpointInstalled() when the breakpoint is first installed in the VM, like what happened in Eclipse 2.0. CC'ing EG for RC3 approval. Darin can you confirm that this is a change in behaviour? There is a change in behavior. In 2.0, we only re-created the underlying JDI request when the breakpoint changed in a way that required the request to be re- created. In 2.1, we always re-create the request whenever a breakpoint attribute changes. This causes the "install" notification to be re-sent when the new request is created.

A target is added on the first "install notification" and removed when the breakpoint is removed from the target. Install notifications are only sent when not already installed.

Bug.Summery: Drag-n-Drop initialization problems.
Bug.WithStack:
In Eclipse 2.0.* versions, we had enabled full drag-n-drop cabability between our viewers. Recently we moved to Eclipse 2.1, however, the drag-n-drop fails to initialize. We add drag adapters like so to our viewer:
int dndOperations = DND.DROP_COPY | DND.DROP_MOVE | DND.DROP_LINK; Transfer[] transfers = new Transfer[] {LocalSelectionTransfer.getInstance()}; viewer.addDragSupport(dndOperations, transfers, new AClass(viewer));
AClass above would be a subclass of DragSourceAdapter. The above code work, and the Drag is enabled for objects of type 'AClass'. However, if I attempt to add another DragSourceAdapter for type 'BClass', this is where the problem comes in.
For example, int dndOperations = DND.DROP_COPY | DND.DROP_MOVE | DND.DROP_LINK; Transfer[] transfers = new Transfer[] {LocalSelectionTransfer.getInstance()}; viewer.addDragSupport(dndOperations, transfers, new BClass(viewer));
It seems any time I attempt to add a second DragSourceAdapter, the initialization fails with with the following exception.
If there is something which has changed with respect to Drag-n-drop initialization, please pass along. thx. Murray
org.eclipse.swt.SWTError: Can not initialize Drag at org.eclipse.swt.dnd.DND.error(DND.java:211) at org.eclipse.swt.dnd.DND.error(DND.java:177) at org.eclipse.swt.dnd.DragSource.<init>(DragSource.java:135) at org.eclipse.jface.viewers.StructuredViewer.addDragSupport(StructuredViewer.j ava:182) at com.ibm.etools.BClass.addDragSourceViewer(BClass.java:32) at com.ibm.etools.ui.view.SampleViewer.initDragAndDrop(SampleViewer.java:20 at com.ibm.etools.ui.view.SampleViewer.createPartControl(SampleViewer.java:136) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.PartPane$4.run(PartPane.java:138) at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.InternalPlatform.run(InternalPlatform.java :867) ...... etc ..... Moving to Veronika.
It is not possible to create multiple drag source objects on the same control.
On some platforms, this results in a segmentation fault and on other platforms, the result is not clear - which drag source will actually provide the data when requested (will the second one be ignored or will it replace the first one, on no platform will both drag source suppliers be available)? Bug.Summery: Cannot install fix if an included feature is at a higher version

Lines.Line: 1) Create a local boolean variable 'patch' as:
2) At the bottom of the method, recurse only if the feature is a patch itself.

Bug.WithStack:
Attempting to install a fix to ftrA if ftrA includes ftrB_1.0.0, but ftrB_1.0.0.1 is installed will fail. The system claims that "updated ftrA (1.0.0.1): Included feature "ftrB(1.0.0)" is older than the currently active feature." However this shouldn't be disallowed. The match statement is not "exact" so it should be permissable to update ftrA even when ftrB is at a higher version than ftrA needs. Reversing the install order (installing ftrA's fix before ftrB's fix) doesn't cause a problem, and overlaying the ftrA fix doesn't cause a problem either. I don't think Update Manager should stop this condition.
Note that this is *not* an update scenario. ftrA and ftrB are being changed as patches (patch="true").
A standalone example is being emailed to Dejan.
Basic install: 'master_1.0.0' includes 'ftrA_1.0.0' 'ftrA_1.0.0' includes 'ftrB_1.0.0'
--- now for the fixes that might be applied: 'fix1_1.0.0' includes 'ftrA_1.0.0.1' and patches 'master_1.0.0' 'fix2_1.0.0' includes 'ftrB_1.0.0.1' and patches 'master_1.0.0' 'ftrA_1.0.0.1' includes 'ftrB_1.0.0' (ie, it doesn't know about or need fix2)
In theory, fix1 and fix2 are independent. They don't require each other and fix separate problems that customers may or may not choose to install.
As it is the only workaround is to have fix2 prereq fix1 so that we force people who want fix2 to install fix1 first. This will get more complicated as more fixes are introduced. When we detect that a feature is an e-fix, we check if the feature it patches is present, but we also check if the features it brings are newer or the same as the ones already present.
This is a prudent check but is too strict in its current implementation. We start from the e-fix root and recurse down the hierachy checking each feature. The recursion is important because e-fixes may include other e-fixes. However, once we reach non-patch children, there is no need to go deeper than immediate non-patch roots.
The fix is therefore to NOT recurse any further if the parent is not an e-fix by itself. The fix:
ActivityConstraints.checkUnique()
1) Create a local boolean variable 'patch' as: boolean patch = isPatch(ifeature);
2) At the bottom of the method, recurse only if the feature is a patch itself.
if (patch) checkUnique(ifeature, features, status);
Released into HEAD (2.1) and 2.0.3 streams.
Will keep open in case we need to ship this as an e-fix for 2.0.3 products. Resolving as fixed.

Bug.Summery: [QuickFix] Using "Local Rename" in "Overwrite" mode has undesired result
Bug.WithStack:
I2003-03-07
Using the "Local Rename" quickfix when the editor's overwrite mode is activated has undesired behavior. The first key press works like normal, the second character overwrites at all positions where the e.g. variable was used, the next characters only overwrite there characters in the place where you are typing. I cannot reproduce it, when this happens is the link feedback gone? Did you do a code assist after the first character? I did not use code assist, just entered the characters. Feedback is partially gone, see screenshot. Created attachment 4208 Stages of typing....
Four parts: Before starting (top), first character typed, second then third. Also happens in Windows XP The "overwrite" mode is causing problems (didn't read careful enough).
Undo works fine.
Moving to JDT-Text for investigation Problem is more general: linked editing has the same problem. Addendum: In insert mode. If when doing the local rename, the cursor ends up the end of the identifier and I delete the next character, the next character is deleted at ALL linked positions. Further character deletes do not have this behaviour. Works for me using R3.2 and newer.
NOTE: if you start typing beyond the linked area then of course the linked mode is exited.

Bug.Summery: Export deployable plugins and fragments does not handle errors
Bug.WithStack:
If I have a plugin that does not compile but still decide to export it using the wizard, my plugin is exported without warnings or errors.
This is bad because the user may consider that its plugin is correct.
We can say that this case is not really a problem because we can assume that this kind of user does not really exists......
But where it becomes really problematic is when the plugin correctly compiles in the workspace, but the build.properties is bogus and the plugin fails to compile through the build.xml. There is a problem with error reporting, which will be looked at in 3.0.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 34972 ***

Bug.Summery: integrated zip tool incorrectly handles filenames with umlauts
Bug.WithStack:
and in Version 2.1
Actually Sun's problem if Eclipse is using Java's zip functionality but thought y'all should report it. Other zip tools (winzip, powerarchiver)don't have a problem with umlauts (ä,ü,ö). In eclipse gebäude is translated into geb+n[with a squiggly on top]ude. For us as programmers this isn't a problem because we never use umlauts, however the users of our product most certainly will. When the filenames are 'destroyed' then other tools using the files have a problem. Closing. It is known that Winzip and java.util.zip use different encodings. Unfortunately, there is no fixed specification for this, so it's a matter of opinion which one is right (and we can't be compatible with both).
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 18648 *** See also bug 21454

Bug.Summery: [Key Bindings] Command descriptions should not use the term "action"
Bug.WithStack:
build I20030317
Many of our command descriptions have the prefix "Action to". We should avoid the implementation term "action" in the UI. Where necessary, we use "command", but this is not needed here. The description should be a simple statement of the command's effect.
For example, the description for File/Close is "Action to close a resource". It should be "Close a resource" (actually, the description could be much improved beyond this, but the prefix is not needed). Kai, can I get your approval for this please? I notice that the new JDT, Debug, Search and Compare command descriptions avoid this pattern. I am willing to fix up the ones in Text as well if you like.
+1 Appreciate your help with the descriptions of the text commands.
I also think it would be good to change the style from imperative to descriptive. E.g. Use "Closes the active editor" rather than "Close the active editor".
However, this would affect all components and this would be too much swirl for RC3. We should probably do this post RC3 though, since it affects only the .properties files.
Fixed for I20030318. Changes reviewed by Andrew.
Kai, in addition to removing the "Action to" prefixes, I made a few corrections to grammar, and a few minor wording changes. The biggest change in your items were to Select Up and Select Down. old: command.selectLineDown.description = Action to select the below line of text command.selectLineUp.description = Action to select the above line of text
new: command.selectLineDown.description = Extend the selection to the next line of text command.selectLineUp.description = Extend the selection to the previous line of text
Verified in I20030318.

Bug.Summery: [resources] ProjectDescription - remove obsolete 'dirty' boolean field
Bug.WithStack: There is a boolean field 'dirty' in the class ProjectDescription and an associated accessor called isDirty(). This was used to do lazy writing of the project description to disk - i.e. check the 'dirty' bit to see if the project description had changed since the last save/snapshot. This logic is not used anymore. Therefore, the field 'dirty', all references to it and the related accessor 'isDirty()' should be removed. Note this is not API. Removed and released.
Bug.WithOutStack: There is a boolean field 'dirty' in the class ProjectDescription and an associated accessor called isDirty(). This was used to do lazy writing of the project description to disk - i.e. check the 'dirty' bit to see if the project description had changed since the last save/snapshot. This logic is not used anymore. Therefore, the field 'dirty', all references to it and the related accessor 'isDirty()' should be removed. Note this is not API. Removed and released.

Bug.Summery: [accessibility] Groups get selected in PaletteViewer with keyboard
Bug.WithStack: Eric, we saw a situation yesterday where we had to press DOWN key twice. Please check to see if groups are being selected. You should temporarily change some of the Logic drawers to groups instead of drawers to test multiple group navigation. Is this fixed? Changed PaletteViewerKeyHandler to not select PaletteGroups. The only exception is the first time the user tabs to the palette after the editor is opened, the SliderPaletteEditPart is selected. When the user presses the down arrow, the group will be selected and another down arrown will place the selection on the first item in the group (the selection tool in the logic example). From that point until the editor file is closed and reopened, groups will not be selected.
Bug.WithOutStack: Eric, we saw a situation yesterday where we had to press DOWN key twice. Please check to see if groups are being selected. You should temporarily change some of the Logic drawers to groups instead of drawers to test multiple group navigation. Is this fixed? Changed PaletteViewerKeyHandler to not select PaletteGroups. The only exception is the first time the user tabs to the palette after the editor is opened, the SliderPaletteEditPart is selected. When the user presses the down arrow, the group will be selected and another down arrown will place the selection on the first item in the group (the selection tool in the logic example). From that point until the editor file is closed and reopened, groups will not be selected.

Bug.Summery: Cannot close connection error on sync all
Bug.WithStack:
build I20030317
In a self-hosting workspace with the org.eclipse.ui module in source, rest in binary, I did a Synchronize CVS projects (all projects). Got an error dialog saying: Cannot close connection. Tried again and it worked. There was nothing in the log. The problem is that, after an exception occurs, if the close throws an exception, the original exception is masked. My guess is the original exception was a timeout. The close should be modified to throw the original exception. This was fixed a while ago

Bug.Summery: Ant adapter should say where to look for the .log file
Bug.WithStack:
Using RC2, in case a compilation failed using the ant adapter in verbose mode, the ant adapter doesn't specify where its log file is. This can easily be improved. I will attach a patch. Created attachment 4212 Patch to fix this issue
Apply this on top of RC2 source code or latest from HEAD. DJ approved it for RC3 Now we report: [javac] Compilation failed. Compiler errors are available in D:\temp\bin.log
Fixed and released in 2.1 HEAD. Verified.

Bug.Summery: Run External Tools not well integrated with Java Browsing.
Bug.WithStack:
Version: 2.1.0 Build id: 200303071024
I want to set up e to invole Sun's javap.exe. Here is what I have in the External Tools dialog:
Location: C:\java\sun\1.4.1_02\bin\javap.exe Arguments: -verbose -c -classpath ${project_loc}/bin ${resource_name}
When I select a Type in the Java Browsing Perspective and invoke javap from e, I get the error: Class 'BasicHCTransaction.java' not found
The description for ${resource_name} is: "Expands to the name of the selected resource". In the context of Java Browsing I expected this to be the class name not the name of the underlying file.
Without better Java integration, I do not see how using Javap or other tools like it is possible. Perhaps Java specific Variables are needed in the External Tools dialog or the Java Browsing Perspective needs to override the meaning of the existing Variable names. I vote for new Java specific Variables like "java_class_name", which is backwards compatible and pretty clear.
Thank you for considering this request.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 35077 *** Note that implementing 35077 as suggested would not fix anything. One needs the class name, NOT the file name without the extension. A class name includes the package of course.

Bug.Summery: [CVS UI] restore from repository dialog shouldn't show deleted revision

Lines.Line: 1) Just filter out the deletion revisions:
Pros:
Simple implementation
Gets rid of clutter
Cons:
Leaves gaps in revision numbering which may confuse users
2) Grey the text of the line for the deleted revisions.
Pros:
Cons:
3) Do #2 but also allow the selection of the deleted revisions *but* update
the Wizards error area and disable the Finish button when deleted revisions
selected. (Can also use the grey feature of the checkbox itself)
Pros:
Gives explicit feedbac as to what is going on.
Cons:
Since the user can select revisions from multiple files at once they may
end up with multiple "errors" that need to be corrected.

Bug.WithStack:
2.1 RC3 When a file is deleted from a CVS repository a revision is created and marked as deleted. This revision cannot be restored but is still shown in the restore dialog. I have investigated and partially implemented proof of concept for a number of solutions to this problem. However, I am not sure which way to go. Many judgement calls would be made. Here is a summary:
1) Just filter out the deletion revisions: Pros: Simple implementation Gets rid of clutter Cons: Leaves gaps in revision numbering which may confuse users
2) Grey the text of the line for the deleted revisions. Pros: Cons:
3) Do #2 but also allow the selection of the deleted revisions *but* update the Wizards error area and disable the Finish button when deleted revisions selected. (Can also use the grey feature of the checkbox itself) Pros: Gives explicit feedbac as to what is going on. Cons: Since the user can select revisions from multiple files at once they may end up with multiple "errors" that need to be corrected.
Created attachment 5202 Change apperance of deleted revisions Released to HEAD by Michael V.
Bug.WithOutStack:
2.1 RC3 When a file is deleted from a CVS repository a revision is created and marked as deleted. This revision cannot be restored but is still shown in the restore dialog. I have investigated and partially implemented proof of concept for a number of solutions to this problem. However, I am not sure which way to go. Many judgement calls would be made. Here is a summary:
1) Just filter out the deletion revisions: Pros: Simple implementation Gets rid of clutter Cons: Leaves gaps in revision numbering which may confuse users
2) Grey the text of the line for the deleted revisions. Pros: Cons:
3) Do #2 but also allow the selection of the deleted revisions *but* update the Wizards error area and disable the Finish button when deleted revisions selected. (Can also use the grey feature of the checkbox itself) Pros: Gives explicit feedbac as to what is going on. Cons: Since the user can select revisions from multiple files at once they may end up with multiple "errors" that need to be corrected.
Created attachment 5202 Change apperance of deleted revisions Released to HEAD by Michael V.

Bug.Summery: cvs slower with RC2 (refreshed with package explorer?)
Bug.WithStack:
Since updating to 2.1 RC2, committing to cvs is much slower. During the commit the cvs decorators for the file and part folders is also flashing.
I'm convienced it relates to the refresh of the decorators in package explorer, but I have not verified this.
Files that would take 1-2 seconds to commit in M5 now take 6+ seconds in RC2. Several performance improvements have been added in RC3. They releate to decorators and other random CVS things that needed fixing. We ran performance tests between RC3 and RC2 and found 20-50% improvements in certain scenarios.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 33156 ***

Bug.Summery: [Action Sets] Hierarchy fast view causes unhandled exceptions

Lines.Line: 1. Open a new resource perspective and reset it.
2. Use "Window->Show View->Other" to open a Hierarchy view (under the Java item
in the dialog). A hierarchy view opens.
3. Drag the hierarchy view to the shortcut bar and drop it there. A fast view
icon for the hierarchy view will be created in the task bar.
4. Click on the hierarchy fast view icon. !BUG! The error message ""Unhandled
exception caught in event loop. Reason: java.lang.NullPointerException" is
displayed in the launch shell, and the view is not displayed correctly on the
workbench screen.
1) created an instance of this without calling init (doing a code search, that
is not the case)
2) we happen to past null in the init argument (again, doing a code search,
that is not the case)
3) dispose() was called (again, doing a code search, that should not happen)
1. remove any existing workspace directory, and start Eclipse
2. Use window->open perspective and choose Java
3. once the Java perspective opens, click on the "hierarchy" tab. The error
message will appear in the launch shell window.
1. Remove the Eclipse workspace directory
2. Launch Eclipse. Eclipse opens with the default resource view and a "Welcome"
editor.
3. Use "Window->Show View->Other" to open a Hierarchy view (under the Java item
in the dialog). A hierarchy view opens stacked over top of the Tasks view.
4. Drag the hierarchy view to the shortcut bar and drop it there. A fast view
icon for the hierarchy view will be created in the task bar.
5. Click on the hierarchy fast view icon. !BUG! The error message ""Unhandled
exception caught in event loop. Reason: java.lang.NullPointerException" is
displayed in the launch shell, and the view is not displayed correctly on the
workbench screen.

Bug.WithStack:
Problem Description: Creating a fast view out of a Hierarchy view and then trying to open it from the short cut bar causes an "Unhandled exception caught in event loop. Reason: java.lang.NullPointerException" message to be printed in the shell window that Eclipse was launched from. The fast view never is displayed on the workbench.
Steps to reproduce: 1. Open a new resource perspective and reset it.
2. Use "Window->Show View->Other" to open a Hierarchy view (under the Java item in the dialog). A hierarchy view opens.
3. Drag the hierarchy view to the shortcut bar and drop it there. A fast view icon for the hierarchy view will be created in the task bar.
4. Click on the hierarchy fast view icon. !BUG! The error message ""Unhandled exception caught in event loop. Reason: java.lang.NullPointerException" is displayed in the launch shell, and the view is not displayed correctly on the workbench screen.
Found in: OS: Solaris 7 Eclipse: V2.1 Build Id: 200303071024 (RC2)
Comments: the fast view icon can be removed by right clicking it and selecting "Close" from the context menu. Could you attach the log? Created attachment 4220 .log file containing info re. the null pointer exception Looks like the PluginActionSet got a null IActionBars somehow. Please investigate as potential RC4 candidate. If I take the 2.1 RC2 build, start it on a new workspace and follow the steps provided above by Rob, I cannot reproduce it on Windows 2000. Will track down a Solaris box to test on that.
Meanwhile, Rob, can you verify if you start with a 2.1 RC2 build with a new workspace, that you can reproduce this problem. Thanks! Verified that it occurs with a brand new workspace in RC2. I just tried on a Solaris box. Installed a new 2.1 RC2 with new workspace. Start up Eclipse, open Hierarchy View (which opens on top of Task view in Resource perspective), d&d Hierarchy view onto shortcut bar, click on Hierarchy view icon to make it visible. No problems. I could not reproduce the problem.
Can you give me the steps you did. Can you tell me what version of Solaris you are running? What vm and version you are using? java -version java version "1.3.1_07" Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.3.1_07-b02) Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.3.1_07-b02, mixed mode)
uname -a SunOS robin 5.7 Generic_106541-23 sun4u sparc SUNW,Ultra-60
Steps to reproduce are exactly as listed, except that I deleted the workspace directory before starting Eclipse. I still have not been able to reproduce this problem. Rob, would you be willing to debug this for us given you have no problem reproducing it. You simply need to lauch a target eclipse in debug mode from your host eclipe (Run > Debug, then create a new "Run-time Workbench")
The stack trace seems to indicate that PluginActionSet has a null value for "bars". Not sure how that can be. Either we
1) created an instance of this without calling init (doing a code search, that is not the case)
2) we happen to past null in the init argument (again, doing a code search, that is not the case)
3) dispose() was called (again, doing a code search, that should not happen)
I would setup everything and then just before showing the Hierarchy view (when its a fast view), place a breakpoint in ActionPresentation.setActionSets
Please let me know what you find out. I have reproduced the problem in RC3, and using a much easier method.
1. remove any existing workspace directory, and start Eclipse
2. Use window->open perspective and choose Java
3. once the Java perspective opens, click on the "hierarchy" tab. The error message will appear in the launch shell window.
OS: HP-UX 11.0, Eclipse V2.1 Build ID: 200303192032 (RC3), Java version 1.3.1_08 Augh! Please ignore last comment: wrong bug #! (sorry) Created attachment 4340 stack trace: 1st time Created attachment 4341 stack trace: 2nd time
"Stack" occured immediately after clicking hierarchy fast view. "stack 2" is 2nd time at breakpoint (but still only 1 original click on fast view button. Also occurs on HP-UX 11.00, Eclipse V2.1 Build ID: 200303192032 (RC3) (fully patched and up-to-date server). See also bug# 35254, for a similar problem with the Hierarchy view. SWT team was able to reproduce this problem on their Solaris box. Moving to SWT team to investigate why the focus change event while creating the tool item. Created attachment 4346 contains tracepoints as requested prior to NullPointerException Comment on attachment 4346 contains tracepoints as requested prior to NullPointerException
corrupted data. will attach corrected version. Created attachment 4347 contains tracepoints as requested prior to NullPointerException Doesn't seem to happen when there is any editor open. Can you confirm this? The behaviour is slightly different (same preparation as before, but closed the "Welcome" editor prior to opening the Hierarchy view).
The first time Hierarchy fast view is clicked, there is no longer a null pointer exception, but the hierarchy view is not displayed properly on the workbench screen (there is a grey outline/border of where it should appear, but no content - the navigator and outline views can still be seen beneath it). Clicking the hierarchy fast view a second time removes this border but now also produces the following error message in the launch shell: Unhandled exception caught in event loop. Reason: java.lang.NullPointerException
Repeatedly clicking the hierarchy fast view toggles between the two results: border with invisible contents, or unhandled exception...
SN says, Kevin, can this be worked around in UI for today's build?
It's going to take us a while to find out the difference between Solaris Motif and Linux Motif that is causing the problem. Even when we find this out, changing code in the area of focus at the 11th hour is not likely to happen. No changes in UI are risky as well.Suggest lowering the priority of this defect to P2 and the SWT team document this bug and suggest workaround in their readme.
Also recommend that the SWT and UI teams work to find a real fix to the problem post 2.1.
Rob do you agree with this resolution?
Fixing in SWT by changing setFocus is too risky. We should make this a ReadMe item instead. Since it doesn't happen if an editor is open and it does not result in the loss of work, it does not sound like a stop ship bug. I will advise ASAP re. acceptability of downgrading.
Veronika and Grant, note that if an editor is open, it DOES happen. I see that I've misinterpreted comment #19.
To clarify: it DOES happen when an editor is open. My comment #20 refers to the test case wherein the editor window (i.e. the lone "Welcome" editor) is closed before clicking the fast view icon. Either way, a problem ensues. We have not been able to reproduce the error when an editor is open. We can cause the error easily when all editors are closed.
If you cause the error once, this may account for continued problems later when an editor is open.
Please give steps to make error happen when an editor is open. The steps I use are as follows:
1. Remove the Eclipse workspace directory
2. Launch Eclipse. Eclipse opens with the default resource view and a "Welcome" editor.
3. Use "Window->Show View->Other" to open a Hierarchy view (under the Java item in the dialog). A hierarchy view opens stacked over top of the Tasks view.
4. Drag the hierarchy view to the shortcut bar and drop it there. A fast view icon for the hierarchy view will be created in the task bar.
5. Click on the hierarchy fast view icon. !BUG! The error message ""Unhandled exception caught in event loop. Reason: java.lang.NullPointerException" is displayed in the launch shell, and the view is not displayed correctly on the workbench screen.
Unless Eclipse stores state information someplace other than the workspace directory, I don't know how a previous error could cause repeat occurrences. After reviewing the impact with the team here, I've lowered the priority to P2 and impact to "major" due to loss of functionality. We would like to review the release note when it is ready. We believe that the problem needs to be fixed, but ASAP after 2.1 is released. Veronika,
Grant and I were able to reproduce the problem on the SWT Solaris machine with the editor open. It happens on the host eclipse, but not on the target eclipse. Actually I don't think it ever happened for us with an open editor. Regardless, I guess this isn't the interesting case since it's not consistent anyways.
Should readme this. Here is the readme item that Jim wrote, which we decided not to include in the 2.1 readme, since it turned out that this problem only occurred on an older version of Motif.
Certain fast views broken (Solaris Motif only) On Solaris, creating a fast view sometime causes an internal exception when the fast view is opened from the short cut bar, and the fast view is not displayed on the workbench. The problem only seems to happen if the fast view does not have a control that takes focus. Examples of problematic views are an empty Hierarchy view and an empty Outline view. (bug 35244) Correction: it was bug 34648 that was only seen on an older version of Motif, not this one. We still decided not to reopen the RC4 candidate to add this readme item.
Note that it is also inaccurate for the readme to state that it is Solaris only. As mentioned above in comment #9, this also occurs on HP-UX.
Fixed > 0409 by fix for bug 19228. Fix released to 2.1.1 stream with SN.

The first time Hierarchy fast view is clicked, there is no longer a null pointer exception, but the hierarchy view is not displayed properly on the workbench screen (there is a grey outline/border of where it should appear, but no content - the navigator and outline views can still be seen beneath it). Clicking the hierarchy fast view a second time removes this border but now also produces the following error message in the launch shell: Unhandled exception caught in event loop. Reason: java.lang.NullPointerException
Repeatedly clicking the hierarchy fast view toggles between the two results: border with invisible contents, or unhandled exception...
SN says, Kevin, can this be worked around in UI for today's build?
It's going to take us a while to find out the difference between Solaris Motif and Linux Motif that is causing the problem. Even when we find this out, changing code in the area of focus at the 11th hour is not likely to happen. No changes in UI are risky as well.Suggest lowering the priority of this defect to P2 and the SWT team document this bug and suggest workaround in their readme.
Also recommend that the SWT and UI teams work to find a real fix to the problem post 2.1.
Rob do you agree with this resolution?
Fixing in SWT by changing setFocus is too risky. We should make this a ReadMe item instead. Since it doesn't happen if an editor is open and it does not result in the loss of work, it does not sound like a stop ship bug. I will advise ASAP re. acceptability of downgrading.
Veronika and Grant, note that if an editor is open, it DOES happen. I see that I've misinterpreted comment #19.
To clarify: it DOES happen when an editor is open. My comment #20 refers to the test case wherein the editor window (i.e. the lone "Welcome" editor) is closed before clicking the fast view icon. Either way, a problem ensues. We have not been able to reproduce the error when an editor is open. We can cause the error easily when all editors are closed.
If you cause the error once, this may account for continued problems later when an editor is open.
Please give steps to make error happen when an editor is open. The steps I use are as follows:
1. Remove the Eclipse workspace directory
2. Launch Eclipse. Eclipse opens with the default resource view and a "Welcome" editor.
3. Use "Window->Show View->Other" to open a Hierarchy view (under the Java item in the dialog). A hierarchy view opens stacked over top of the Tasks view.
4. Drag the hierarchy view to the shortcut bar and drop it there. A fast view icon for the hierarchy view will be created in the task bar.
5. Click on the hierarchy fast view icon. !BUG! The error message ""Unhandled exception caught in event loop. Reason: java.lang.NullPointerException" is displayed in the launch shell, and the view is not displayed correctly on the workbench screen.
Unless Eclipse stores state information someplace other than the workspace directory, I don't know how a previous error could cause repeat occurrences. After reviewing the impact with the team here, I've lowered the priority to P2 and impact to "major" due to loss of functionality. We would like to review the release note when it is ready. We believe that the problem needs to be fixed, but ASAP after 2.1 is released. Veronika,
Grant and I were able to reproduce the problem on the SWT Solaris machine with the editor open. It happens on the host eclipse, but not on the target eclipse. Actually I don't think it ever happened for us with an open editor. Regardless, I guess this isn't the interesting case since it's not consistent anyways.
Should readme this. Here is the readme item that Jim wrote, which we decided not to include in the 2.1 readme, since it turned out that this problem only occurred on an older version of Motif.
Certain fast views broken (Solaris Motif only) On Solaris, creating a fast view sometime causes an internal exception when the fast view is opened from the short cut bar, and the fast view is not displayed on the workbench. The problem only seems to happen if the fast view does not have a control that takes focus. Examples of problematic views are an empty Hierarchy view and an empty Outline view. (bug 35244) Correction: it was bug 34648 that was only seen on an older version of Motif, not this one. We still decided not to reopen the RC4 candidate to add this readme item.
Note that it is also inaccurate for the readme to state that it is Solaris only. As mentioned above in comment #9, this also occurs on HP-UX.
Fixed > 0409 by fix for bug 19228. Fix released to 2.1.1 stream with SN.

Lines.Line: - create a Java project
- add a Jar to it without putting it onto the build path (don't make it a
java element)
- open properties->Source attachment
i think there should be another entry in the log avove that one
can you look?
the problem comes i think from JavadocConfigurationPropertyPage.getJavaElement

Bug.WithStack:
Win32 - 2.1 I0317 I have a project that contains a single JAR. If I select the Javadoc location option under Properties of the JAR, the following exception occurs: java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.corext.javadoc.JavaDocLocations.getJavadocBaseLocation (JavaDocLocations.java:164) at org.eclipse.jdt.ui.JavaUI.getJavadocBaseLocation(JavaUI.java:710) at (PreferencePage.java:215) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.preferences.JavadocConfigurationPropertyPage.create Control(JavadocConfigurationPropertyPage.java:63) at org.eclipse.jface.preference.PreferenceDialog.showPage (PreferenceDialog.java:1017) at org.eclipse.jface.preference.PreferenceDialog$9.run (PreferenceDialog.java:496) at org.eclipse.swt.custom.BusyIndicator.showWhile (BusyIndicator.java:69) at org.eclipse.jface.preference.PreferenceDialog$8.widgetSelected (PreferenceDialog.java:490) at org.eclipse.jface.util.OpenStrategy.firePostSelectionEvent (OpenStrategy.java:198) at org.eclipse.jface.util.OpenStrategy.access$4(OpenStrategy.java:193) at org.eclipse.jface.util.OpenStrategy$3.run(OpenStrategy.java:333) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.RunnableLock.run(RunnableLock.java:35) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Synchronizer.runAsyncMessages (Synchronizer.java:98) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.runAsyncMessages(Display.java:1758) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.readAndDispatch(Display.java:1493) at org.eclipse.jface.window.Window.runEventLoop(Window.java:583) at org.eclipse.jface.window.Window.open(Window.java:563) at org.eclipse.ui.dialogs.PropertyDialogAction.run (PropertyDialogAction.java:164) at org.eclipse.jface.action.Action.runWithEvent(Action.java:842) at org.eclipse.jface.action.ActionContributionItem.handleWidgetSelection (ActionContributionItem.java:456) at org.eclipse.jface.action.ActionContributionItem.handleWidgetEvent (ActionContributionItem.java:403) at org.eclipse.jface.action.ActionContributionItem.access$0 (ActionContributionItem.java:397) at org.eclipse.jface.action.ActionContributionItem$ActionListener.handleEvent (ActionContributionItem.java:72) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.EventTable.sendEvent(EventTable.java:81) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.sendEvent(Widget.java:840) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.runDeferredEvents(Display.java:1781) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.readAndDispatch(Display.java:1489) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runEventLoop(Workbench.java:1402) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.run(Workbench.java:1385) at org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.InternalBootLoader.run (InternalBootLoader.java:845) at org.eclipse.core.boot.BootLoader.run(BootLoader.java:461) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke (NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39) at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke (DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25) at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:324) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:247) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:703) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:539) Steps to reproduce:
- create a Java project - add a Jar to it without putting it onto the build path (don't make it a java element) - open properties->Source attachment i think there should be another entry in the log avove that one can you look? the problem comes i think from JavadocConfigurationPropertyPage.getJavaElement
in the case when a CoreException is thrown and caught, that method returns null, which ends up in JavaDocLocations.getJavadocBaseLocation as elem This is not a regression. The problem is that, since the jar isn't on the class path, it is not a Java element. Even if we make the property page work when selected, we can't store the enterned value since a javadoc location can only be attached to a Java element.
The fix would be to present a label for jar not on the class path telling the user that a javadoc location can only be set for Jar's on the class path.
I tested the fix proposed by adam. But this only postpones the NPE until the user hits OK.
Martin pls investigate a minimal fix for RC3 Created attachment 4237 fix
Full fix of the problem. Attaching a URL to a JAR not on the classpath is allowed as long as it is a Java project. suggest to fix. Fix is to be more precise in deciding which elements can have javadoc locations ('getJavaElement'), to prevent the NPE and to hide the controls in that case. +1 +1 Martin please release after review fixed for 20030319 reviewed by Adam verified for RC3

Bug.Summery: non-uniform capitalization of command line options
Bug.WithStack:
In the "Running Eclipse" task (user's docs):
org.eclipse.platform.doc.user\tasks\running_eclipse.htm
there are some options that use capitalization (classloaderProperties, noLazyRegistryCacheLoading) on compound names and others that do not (plugincustomization, consolelog, showlocation, showsplash, endsplash, nosplash, noregistrycache).
We should commit to one of the notations (no capitalization was the standard until 2.0.1). Have generated bug http://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=35603 as this is wrong in the code as well as the doc. In the code, however, we use case insensitive string comparisons so we should be okay to change the doc.
Have changed references to -nolazyregistrycacheloading and - classloaderproperties (which had capitals).

Bug.Summery: "New Folder"
Bug.WithStack:
Creating a new folder, file, etc. with the New->wizard is painfully slow with RC2. I believe this was the case with RC1 as well.
It takes 5-15 seconds for what I type to appear in the text field. It then takes an addition 5-15 seconds for it to recongize that I it the "finish" button. For the dialog to complete and close then takes anywhere from 1 minute to over 5 minutes.
In a new workdspace with a small amunt of projects, there doesn't appear to be a problem. However, in my normal workspace with 46 projects, it is extremely sluggish. Does it speed up if you turn off decorations (Window > Preferences > Workbench > Label Decorations)?
This was a bug in the decorators that showed up mostly in the new file dialog. Marking as dup of Bug 28343
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 28343 *** Your assumption is correct. When I turn off cvs decorators (the only decorator I had turned on), behavior is as expected (no noticable delays).

Bug.Summery: Unhandled exception caught in event loop. Reason:Widget is disposed

Lines.Line: 1. Open Eclipse, and select any perspective.
2. Move the existing views such that there are no tabbed (stacked) views.
3. Use Window->Show Views to add all possible views (including the SWT
Examples). Re-arrange views such that there are no tabbed/stacked views (it
will be difficult to see the titles of some views during this process).
4. Select a new perspective, or exit Eclipse using File->Exit. The shell that
Eclipse was launched from will display the following error message:
"Unhandled Exception caught in event loop.
Reason:
Widget is disposed".
1. opening Eclipse with a brand new workspace
2. opening all possible views by selecting them from the Window->Show View
dialog (shift-selected all of them after opening each item in the dialog tree)
3. Dragged views from stacked views to new locations such that all views are
visible (but not necessarily big enough to be useful) with no stacking of views.
1. remove any existing workspace directory, and start Eclipse
2. Use window->open perspective and choose Java
3. once the Java perspective opens, click on the "hierarchy" tab. The error
message will appear in the launch shell window.
- start a completely new eclipse workspace
- open the Java Type Hierarchy perspective
- open the Plug-in Development perspective
- switch to the opened Java Type Hierarchy perspective
- switch to the opened Plug-in Development perspective

Bug.WithStack:
Problem Description: After opening all possible views and moving them such that there are no overlapping views on the workbench (stress-testing suite), I used File->Exit to close the workbench (investigating bug 33577). After the workbench closed, I noticed a message in the launch shell window saying "Unhandled exception caught in event loop. Reason:Widget is disposed".
Note: This differs from bug 33577 in that there is no spinning process: the workbench closes after saving the workspace.
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open Eclipse, and select any perspective.
2. Move the existing views such that there are no tabbed (stacked) views.
3. Use Window->Show Views to add all possible views (including the SWT Examples). Re-arrange views such that there are no tabbed/stacked views (it will be difficult to see the titles of some views during this process).
4. Select a new perspective, or exit Eclipse using File->Exit. The shell that Eclipse was launched from will display the following error message: "Unhandled Exception caught in event loop. Reason: Widget is disposed".
Found in: OS: HP-UX 11.00. Eclipse: V2.1 Build Id: 200303071024 (RC2) Created attachment 4221 Widget is disposed... log file Rob, the stack trace indicates that you were clicking on a tab folder, rather than switching perspectives or shutting down. Do you see the message when you switch perspectives or on shutdown, or does it appear when rearranging the views?
Andrew, could you please try to reproduce this? I didn't notice the message until I had closed Eclipse, so it may have occurred prior to closing, while I was rearranging all the views. I used a combination of dragging some views by their menu bar and some by dragging their tab. I'll see if I can pin down more exactly what causes the message. I saw the message while dragging a view by its title bar to a new location on the worbench (paned views stress test). I've attached the log file. I reproduced it by:
1. opening Eclipse with a brand new workspace
2. opening all possible views by selecting them from the Window->Show View dialog (shift-selected all of them after opening each item in the dialog tree)
3. Dragged views from stacked views to new locations such that all views are visible (but not necessarily big enough to be useful) with no stacking of views.
The message appeared after moving almost all the views (only 2 left stacked). Created attachment 4243 another WID log file Eclipse I200303182359 I have tried to reproduce this with HP-UX, RH8.0 gtk, RH8.0 motif and Windows XP. In all cases I do not get an error.
Can you please attach the output from Window->About Eclipse->Configuration Details. Created attachment 4246 Configuration info (via Eclipse Window->About Eclipse->Configuration Details) Rob,
The Configuration information (comment #8) does not include the exception you reported. Was this from the same machine? Did you clear the .log file? Are you using a different workspace? The log file attached via comment #6 should have the info - does it not? It is the content of the .metadata/.log file.
The log attached via comment #8 was after the log file had been reset and no error had yet occurred - I didn't realize you were looking for another example of the error. Let me know if the other two log files don't have the info you need. No problem. Wasn't actually looking for other examples of that error, just what else was going on, i.e. were there other logs generated with that one.
I do have a question about the logs I did see. Did anything strange happen when you started eclipse? I see two java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/eclipse/swt/widgets/Decorations
Do you know what generated them? If so a separate bug should be logged. See bug #31956 for a bug with a possible similar trace (they did not provide an actual trace, just the summary). Hmmm. I think it would be best to ignore attachment from #8. I suspect that some of the work I was doing this morning (running java and Eclipse in a debugger to try to catch the SIGSEG trap (bug #34916)) strayed into the log file; I know I was having java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError problems at the beginning until I got all the parameters worked out. I think the java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError is a red herring, unless you saw it in the first two log files. Rob,
When RC3 is delivered could you try and reproduce this bug, capturing the full output from the Configuration Details. That way I can see if any other logs are leading up to the problem. I have had no success in reproducing this bug with the I200303182359 build on HP-UX, linux or Windows. Meanwhile I will use the log from comment #6 to look at the code. I have reproduced the problem in RC3, and using a much easier method.
1. remove any existing workspace directory, and start Eclipse
2. Use window->open perspective and choose Java
3. once the Java perspective opens, click on the "hierarchy" tab. The error message will appear in the launch shell window.
OS: HP-UX 11.0, Eclipse V2.1 Build ID: 200303192032 (RC3), Java version 1.3.1_08

Bug.WithOutStack:
Problem Description: After opening all possible views and moving them such that there are no overlapping views on the workbench (stress-testing suite), I used File->Exit to close the workbench (investigating bug 33577). After the workbench closed, I noticed a message in the launch shell window saying "Unhandled exception caught in event loop. Reason:Widget is disposed".
Note: This differs from bug 33577 in that there is no spinning process: the workbench closes after saving the workspace.
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open Eclipse, and select any perspective.

3. Use Window->Show Views to add all possible views (including the SWT Examples). Re-arrange views such that there are no tabbed/stacked views (it will be difficult to see the titles of some views during this process).
4. Select a new perspective, or exit Eclipse using File->Exit. The shell that Eclipse was launched from will display the following error message: "Unhandled Exception caught in event loop. Reason: Widget is disposed".
Found in: OS: HP-UX 11.00. Eclipse: V2.1 Build Id: 200303071024 (RC2) Created attachment 4221 Widget is disposed... log file Rob, the stack trace indicates that you were clicking on a tab folder, rather than switching perspectives or shutting down. Do you see the message when you switch perspectives or on shutdown, or does it appear when rearranging the views?

I used a combination of dragging some views by their menu bar and some by dragging their tab. I'll see if I can pin down more exactly what causes the message. 1. opening Eclipse with a brand new workspace
2. opening all possible views by selecting them from the Window->Show View dialog (shift-selected all of them after opening each item in the dialog tree)

The message appeared after moving almost all the views (only 2 left stacked). Created attachment 4243 another WID log file Eclipse I200303182359 I have tried to reproduce this with HP-UX, RH8.0 gtk, RH8.0 motif and Windows XP. In all cases I do not get an error.

Let me know if the other two log files don't have the info you need. No problem. Wasn't actually looking for other examples of that error, just what else was going on, i.e. were there other logs generated with that one.

Do you know what generated them? If so a separate bug should be logged. See bug #31956 for a bug with a possible similar trace (they did not provide an actual trace, just the summary). Hmmm. I think it would be best to ignore attachment from #8. I suspect that some of the work I was doing this morning (running java and Eclipse in a debugger to try to catch the SIGSEG trap (bug #34916)) strayed into the log file; I know I was having java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError problems at the beginning until I got all the parameters worked out. Bug.Summery: 2.1 RC2; White space help working set name problems.

Lines.Line: 1. Using help browser it is possible to give working set a name that consists
of white space, than perform a search. It should not be allowed - when
creating working set in the workbench whitespace name is not allowed.
2. Clicking Search scope again opens a dialog that does not show this working
set. The working set cannot be edited or deleted from the help browser.
However the workbench working set dialog is capable of displaying these working
sets and they can be deleted there.
Fixed.
Added a check for first char being a white space in enableOK() method.
As long as the first char is a white space, the ok button is never enabled.
Verfied in RC3 that fix works as described. It would be nicer to ignore
leading and trailing white space, and enable OK button when there is a non
white space character entered, but that would be a nice to have enhancement.

As long as the first char is a white space, the ok button is never enabled. Verfied in RC3 that fix works as described. Bug.Summery: 2.1 RC2; No related links if custom brower is used.
Bug.WithStack:
Choose custom browswer in help preferences. Leave the default command, or set to a progream. Close preferences. Press F1, click a related link. Result: Browser opens to a links page, but does not display a topic or related links.
Same problem when selecting a search result in the workbench. Help opens to search page, but the search field is empty, search results view is empty, and topic selected is not displayed (a help welcome page is shown instead).
It looks like the brower receives the URL parameter only up to the first "&" character that is used to separate GGI parameters in the URL. The rest of the URL is consummed by OS shell, in which the browser is launched. Part of the problem is that Custom browser is prepending the command that user specified with "cmd.exe /c", that is required to launch sytem commands, but in case of launching IExplore.exe it is not needed. If I point custom browser to IExplore or mozilla.exe in the preferences, and have the code that adds "cmd.exe /c" commented out, then search results and links show correctly.
Fixed. Verified in RC3
Bug.WithOutStack:
Choose custom browswer in help preferences. Leave the default command, or set to a progream. Close preferences. Press F1, click a related link. Result: Browser opens to a links page, but does not display a topic or related links.
Same problem when selecting a search result in the workbench. Help opens to search page, but the search field is empty, search results view is empty, and topic selected is not displayed (a help welcome page is shown instead).
It looks like the brower receives the URL parameter only up to the first "&" character that is used to separate GGI parameters in the URL. The rest of the URL is consummed by OS shell, in which the browser is launched. Part of the problem is that Custom browser is prepending the command that user specified with "cmd.exe /c", that is required to launch sytem commands, but in case of launching IExplore.exe it is not needed. If I point custom browser to IExplore or mozilla.exe in the preferences, and have the code that adds "cmd.exe /c" commented out, then search results and links show correctly.
Fixed. Verified in RC3

Bug.Summery: Log pollution on server
Bug.WithStack: If you turn on debug logging in the server, the console becomes totally flooded with log messages from org.eclipse.stellation.remote.engine.Engine.acceptConnection at line 429. It floods the log console to the point where the debugger becomes unresponsive.
Bug.WithOutStack: If you turn on debug logging in the server, the console becomes totally flooded with log messages from org.eclipse.stellation.remote.engine.Engine.acceptConnection at line 429. I have commented this out on my machine and I think we should leave this commented out unless troubleshooting a specific problem where this log message might be useful. It floods the log console to the point where the debugger becomes unresponsive.

Bug.Summery: Windows Port Patch

Lines.Line: a) stop server (if running)
b) if necessary, modify stellation.test.properties to select remote mode or
other settings
c) in org.eclipse.stellation.core/test, run "ant force-init" to create and
initialize a clean test db
d) start server (e.g. via runserver.bat or runserver.sh)
e) in a separate console window, run the remote tests: in
org.eclipse.stellation.core/test, run "ant"
- manually delete the old test db (e.g. 'dropdb tsvctest' ),
- create an empty test db (e.g. 'createdb tsvctest')
- initialize the db for use by Stellation (e.g. 'tsvcadmin .....').
- The test and build property files are copied into ${user.home}/stellation.
On my Win2K system, this resolves to
"C:\Documents and Settings\jwright\stellation"
- The scripts and library files are copied to locations under ${inst.path}.
On my Win2K system, this resolves to "C:\Program Files\Stellation"

Bug.WithStack:
Here is the patch for Windows. It is a fairly big one as it includes fixes for a few Windows and Firebird problems as well as extensive modifications to the script files to support Windows and Firebird. Included with the ant scripts are two model property files that are intended to be copied to a user's home directory and then edited for local preferences.
Also note that the default installation location for Windows will be \Program Files\Stellation with the rest of the install tree the same as Linux. Created attachment 4235 Zip of all patch files
You will need to filter out .classpath and .project in core.patch. I was unable to convince Eclipse to ignore them. I've checked this, and encountered a couple of problems.
There are a few patch glitches, which look like tab-related issues. They're no big deal. But the patch build-core.xml in the core project doesn't match up at all, and can't be applied. So it's a no-go, until we can figure out what's wrong.
I'd suggest checking if you're up to date with the repository - the kinds of other glitches that I saw look like the kinds of things that could happen if you missed one checkin, and there was a recent checkin that included a bunch of build-file changes. Created attachment 4566 The complete build-core.xml file
This should allow you to moveahead. The work on this item has been completed and checked in with tag jfg-35267. Created attachment 4771 Ant build scripts, test scripts and related files for Windows and Linux
This zip contains a set of scripts and associated files which have been tested on both Win2K and Linux (RH7.3) systems, in both local-server and remote-server test modes.
Zip contents include: - build-core.xml, stellation.build.properties used for building and installing Stellation
- test/build.xml, test/stellation.test.properties used for testing the installation
- test/runserver.bat, test/runserver.sh used for launching a Stellation server for remote-mode testing
Build and Test Script Changes
- changed build-core.xml (build script) and test/build.xml (test script) to create stellation.build.properties and stellation.test.properties if not found, using default settings
- changed build.xml to fail with appropriate message if stellation.build.properties does not contain all settings required) (note: this failure occurs by design when the default stellation.test.properties file is created).
- added force-init target to build.xml. This is needed to properly set up a remote test using a localhost server. The remote test procedure is: a) stop server (if running) b) if necessary, modify stellation.test.properties to select remote mode or other settings c) in org.eclipse.stellation.core/test, run "ant force-init" to create and initialize a clean test db d) start server (e.g. via runserver.bat or runserver.sh) e) in a separate console window, run the remote tests: in org.eclipse.stellation.core/test, run "ant"
This is **different** (and more convenient) than the previous test procedure. Formerly, it was necessary to: - manually delete the old test db (e.g. 'dropdb tsvctest' ), - create an empty test db (e.g. 'createdb tsvctest') - initialize the db for use by Stellation (e.g. 'tsvcadmin .....').
Now, "ant force-init" does the whole job.
Script Additions
- added test/runserver.sh and test/runserver.bat scripts to conveniently launch a Stellation server for remote-mode testing. These scripts include hard-coded database pathnames, and require customization before use. They also enable verbose debug output and logging to a file.
Other Notes
"ant -verbose some >test.log 2>&1" is very useful when debugging the test script. This command-line redirects all output to test.log, and runs a single test rather than the full set of 14.
The '+' separator _must_ be used within the repository location specifier. The previous separator, ':', is now treated as a legal pathname character.
Windows pathnames in property and batch files should use '/', not '\' . Use of '\' causes weird problems (e.g. damaged pathnames) because it is sometimes interpreted as an escape character.
Under Windows, "installed" files are put in possibly-surprising locations. - The test and build property files are copied into ${user.home}/stellation. On my Win2K system, this resolves to "C:\Documents and Settings\jwright\stellation" - The scripts and library files are copied to locations under ${inst.path}. On my Win2K system, this resolves to "C:\Program Files\Stellation"
Also - a number of 3rd-party libraries are needed for the installation. The build-core.xml install target expects to find these libraries in ${build.class.lib}, which defaults to ${user.home}/stellation/lib. On my Win2K system, this resolves to "C:\Documents and Settings\jwright\stellation\lib" .
All of these default locations may be changed by appropriate use of the stellation.build.properties and stellation.test.properties files.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Here is the patch for Windows. It is a fairly big one as it includes fixes for a few Windows and Firebird problems as well as extensive modifications to the script files to support Windows and Firebird. Included with the ant scripts are two model property files that are intended to be copied to a user's home directory and then edited for local preferences.
Also note that the default installation location for Windows will be \Program Files\Stellation with the rest of the install tree the same as Linux. Created attachment 4235 Zip of all patch files

Zip contents include: - build-core.xml, stellation.build.properties used for building and installing Stellation
- test/build.xml, test/stellation.test.properties used for testing the installation
- test/runserver.bat, test/runserver.sh used for launching a Stellation server for remote-mode testing
Build and Test Script Changes
- changed build-core.xml (build script) and test/build.xml (test script) to create stellation.build.properties and stellation.test.properties if not found, using default settings
- changed build.xml to fail with appropriate message if stellation.build.properties does not contain all settings required) (note: this failure occurs by design when the default stellation.test.properties file is created).
- added force-init target to build.xml. This is needed to properly set up a remote test using a localhost server. The remote test procedure is: a) stop server (if running) b) if necessary, modify stellation.test.properties to select remote mode or other settings c) in org.eclipse.stellation.core/test, run "ant force-init" to create and initialize a clean test db d) start server (e.g. via runserver.bat or runserver.sh) e) in a separate console window, run the remote tests: in org.eclipse.stellation.core/test, run "ant"
This is **different** (and more convenient) than the previous test procedure. Formerly, it was necessary to: - manually delete the old test db (e.g. 'dropdb tsvctest' ), - create an empty test db (e.g. 'createdb tsvctest') - initialize the db for use by Stellation (e.g. 'tsvcadmin .....').
Now, "ant force-init" does the whole job.
Script Additions
- added test/runserver.sh and test/runserver.bat scripts to conveniently launch a Stellation server for remote-mode testing. These scripts include hard-coded database pathnames, and require customization before use. They also enable verbose debug output and logging to a file.
Other Notes
"ant -verbose some >test.log 2>&1" is very useful when debugging the test script. This command-line redirects all output to test.log, and runs a single test rather than the full set of 14.
The '+' separator _must_ be used within the repository location specifier. The previous separator, ':', is now treated as a legal pathname character.
Windows pathnames in property and batch files should use '/', not '\' . Use of '\' causes weird problems (e.g. damaged pathnames) because it is sometimes interpreted as an escape character.
Under Windows, "installed" files are put in possibly-surprising locations. - The test and build property files are copied into ${user.home}/stellation. On my Win2K system, this resolves to "C:\Documents and Settings\jwright\stellation" - The scripts and library files are copied to locations under ${inst.path}. On my Win2K system, this resolves to "C:\Program Files\Stellation"
Also - a number of 3rd-party libraries are needed for the installation. The build-core.xml install target expects to find these libraries in ${build.class.lib}, which defaults to ${user.home}/stellation/lib. On my Win2K system, this resolves to "C:\Documents and Settings\jwright\stellation\lib" .
All of these default locations may be changed by appropriate use of the stellation.build.properties and stellation.test.properties files.

Bug.Summery: Default classpath has to be selected twice to update
Bug.WithStack:
In the Create, Manage, and Run Configurations screen, select the Classpath tab. For a configuration that has a custom classpath, I need to select the "Use default classpath" checkbox twice in order for the classpath to reset. This showed up in RC2 and I don't remember it in RC1.
Actually, even more preferable would be if the configuration classpath could be built with something like "base default classpath" + "some custom classpath". Currently, I have to keep updating all the custom classpaths when the base default classpath changes. Presumably this is a launch configuration issue. Fixed. The same problem existed on the source lookup tab. To reproduce I had to: * Create a non-default classpath (or source path) * save the config * close the dialog * re-open the dialog on the config * click the "use default" button -> did not update
The problem was that the dirty flag was set too late in the process, and the working copy was not updated with the "default" attribute before the classpath was re-computed (and thus, the same classpath was recomputed). Please verify, Joe. Verified.

Actually, even more preferable would be if the configuration classpath could be built with something like "base default classpath" + "some custom classpath". Currently, I have to keep updating all the custom classpaths when the base default classpath changes. Presumably this is a launch configuration issue. Fixed. The same problem existed on the source lookup tab. To reproduce I had to: * Create a non-default classpath (or source path) * save the config * close the dialog * re-open the dialog on the config * click the "use default" button -> did not update
The problem was that the dirty flag was set too late in the process, and the working copy was not updated with the "default" attribute before the classpath was re-computed (and thus, the same classpath was recomputed). Please verify, Joe. Verified.

Bug.Summery: Please make it easier to add .jar files to a project's classpath. [build path]
Bug.WithStack:
I've been using Eclipse since it was first available. Adding .jar files to my project has always, and I mean always, caused me heartache. The easiest solution I could think of is for the JDT to automatically add any jar files found in the .\Project\jars directory. Just like source is added from the .\Project\source directory. Refreshing the project would update the jar list along with the source files.
I probably have between 3 and 5 projects going at any one time. I rarely use a particular jar in more than single project. My proposed solution does nothing for people who want to share a single jar across many projects. (Sorry, I haven't given it any thought.) Moving to JDT/UI for comment. This is not critical enough for 2.1 (we are already working on release candidate 3). Postponing > 2.1 As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: ant support ignores update keyword when building a jar file
Bug.WithStack:
i have a ant script that updates the contents of an *existing* jar file. the script works fine when started from the command line but not when run from eclipse. instead of updating the existing jar eclipse erases the old one and creates a new one.
this is the part of the ant script:
<target name="jar" depends="timestamp"> <jar jarfile="${target.dir}/lib/${target.jar.file}.jar" basedir="${basedir}/classes" excludes="**/*.class" manifest="${basedir}/build/manifest.mf" update="yes"/> </target>
eclipse ant support seems to ignore the update="yes" statement Mark, when you are running from the command line, are you using Ant 1.5.2? Darin, i used 1.4.1 for my work. Based on your feedback I tested my script with 1.5.2 on the command line. I used the Ant jar files from the Eclipse RC2 distribution. I can reproduce the error with this version. So it really seams to be a problem with Ant 1.5.2.
Any idea if this is a know Ant bug?
Mark, I know that Ant has had trouble with the zip / jar tasks in 1.5.2. I don't know all the specifics. I would recommend you ask on the Ant user group. Both the dev and user groups can be viewed at http://ant.apache.org/mail.html

Bug.Summery: leak in pde editor

Lines.Line: 1) Source page created but didn't dispose the outline page. Fixed.
2) AbstractForm added an anonymous property change listener to preference
store. Since this object was never removed, it kept editor and a bunch of its
classes from being collected. Fixed by creating a private field and explicitly
calling 'removePropertyChangeListener' on that field in 'dispose' method.

Bug.WithStack:
20030318 scenario:
open pde plugin.xml editor close it gc count instances open pde plugin.xml editor close it gc
attached is the heap data filtered to instances of classes *eclipse*pde* Created attachment 4240 heap data (only *eclipse*pde* classes are shown) Good catch.
We found two problems, one related to source page only, another related to form pages.
1) Source page created but didn't dispose the outline page. Fixed. 2) AbstractForm added an anonymous property change listener to preference store. Since this object was never removed, it kept editor and a bunch of its classes from being collected. Fixed by creating a private field and explicitly calling 'removePropertyChangeListener' on that field in 'dispose' method.
Build the JARs, placed them in I20030318 and tried OptimizeIt again - this time no editor classes found in the heap delta.
Bug.WithOutStack:
20030318 scenario:
open pde plugin.xml editor close it gc count instances open pde plugin.xml editor close it gc
attached is the heap data filtered to instances of classes *eclipse*pde* Created attachment 4240 heap data (only *eclipse*pde* classes are shown) Good catch.
We found two problems, one related to source page only, another related to form pages.
1) Source page created but didn't dispose the outline page. Fixed. 2) AbstractForm added an anonymous property change listener to preference store. Since this object was never removed, it kept editor and a bunch of its classes from being collected. Fixed by creating a private field and explicitly calling 'removePropertyChangeListener' on that field in 'dispose' method.
Build the JARs, placed them in I20030318 and tried OptimizeIt again - this time no editor classes found in the heap delta.

Bug.Summery: Eclipse hangs while creating a new directory

Lines.Line: - which VM you're using
- any command line args
- whether it hangs at 100% cpu usage or 0

Bug.WithStack:
I have discovered a weird bug, in 2.1 RC2, Eclipse seems to hang during directory creation. Following happens, from the navigator pane, use: new->folder from the context menu, the new folder dialog pops open, enter a name and press ok, the dialog itself seems to run in an endless loop at this stage. Werner, if you can reproduce this, could you please try the following: run eclipse with: eclipse -vm {yourJRELocation}/bin/java -data {yourWorkspaceLocation}
when it hangs, send a kill -3 to the process. This should get it to generate a file containing stack dumps for all the threads.
You could also try the latest integration build, since we have addressed several hang and deadlock problems since RC2 (we are building the RC3 candidate today).
Could you also please indicate: - which VM you're using - any command line args - whether it hangs at 100% cpu usage or 0
See also bug 35044, another deadlock when creating a folder, this time on Windows.
Andrew, can you investigate these please? Werner, is there anything special about your setup? Are you using just the plain eclipse SDK, or are there other plugins installed? Werner,
Please attach the output from the configuration details (Help->About Eclipse- >Configuration Details. Created attachment 4245 The configuration which causes the problem
Note I use Blackdown J2SDK 1.4.1 but I can reproduce the bug with a standard Sun JDK as well. The Motif version is not affected however. Just a note, the command line argument -Xmx200m must be the last argument to take effect, otherwise it is ignored. Ok I forgot, extra Plugins installed:
Planty (Ant Editor Plugin latest version from the net) VeloEdit (same for Velocity) and Jalopy (Sourcecode Formatter)
Machine configuration: Generic Gentoo Linux, with a 2.4.20 CK4 Kernel which has preemtive scheduling and low latency enabled. The system is running on a ReiserFS partition, XFree 4.2.1 GTK 2.2.1/GTK 1.2.10-r9 Processor Athlon TBird 900, 700MB Ram
as for the -Xmx200, thanks for the hint, but didn't solve the problem because it already is like that: here my startup script:
#!/bin/sh cd /home/werpu/development/eclipse ./eclipse -vm /opt/blackdown-j2sdk1.4.1/bin/java -Xmx 200m
Sorry, I just noticed the bug with the blank in -Xmx200m in my startup script, corrected it, but doesn't help with the problem, the memory doesn't really seem to be the issue, my personal guess is some kind of concurrency problem/deadlock I'm running into in the create directory dialog since I run an optimized kernel.
Werner, when it hangs, which processes are consuming CPU? We've seen various hanging problems on GTK 2.1.1, which sometimes show CPU split between the X server and eclipse java vm at about 60%/30%. We haven't done much testing on GTK 2.2 or GTK 2.2.1 since we've been having a hard time actually getting a stable install of it on RedHat 8 or 8.1.
Felipe, are you aware of any such hang problems in RC2?
Unfortunately I'm out of the office right now, so I can't really test. But I went on from a clean installation on my home pc (pretty similar config) and installed the plugins. The problem is not reproducable here. My personal guess now goes towards a problematic project file (the project files were rather old, imported from 2.0 by moving the desktop). I will give it a try tomorrow as soon as I am back in the office. See Bug31525, comment 46.
