Bug.WithOutStack:
I have discovered a weird bug, in 2.1 RC2, Eclipse seems to hang during directory creation. Following happens, from the navigator pane, use: new->folder from the context menu, the new folder dialog pops open, enter a name and press ok, the dialog itself seems to run in an endless loop at this stage. Werner, if you can reproduce this, could you please try the following: run eclipse with: eclipse -vm {yourJRELocation}/bin/java -data {yourWorkspaceLocation}
when it hangs, send a kill -3 to the process. This should get it to generate a file containing stack dumps for all the threads.
You could also try the latest integration build, since we have addressed several hang and deadlock problems since RC2 (we are building the RC3 candidate today).
Could you also please indicate: - which VM you're using - any command line args - whether it hangs at 100% cpu usage or 0
See also bug 35044, another deadlock when creating a folder, this time on Windows.
Andrew, can you investigate these please? Werner, is there anything special about your setup? Are you using just the plain eclipse SDK, or are there other plugins installed? Werner,
Please attach the output from the configuration details (Help->About Eclipse- >Configuration Details. Created attachment 4245 The configuration which causes the problem
Note I use Blackdown J2SDK 1.4.1 but I can reproduce the bug with a standard Sun JDK as well. The Motif version is not affected however. Just a note, the command line argument -Xmx200m must be the last argument to take effect, otherwise it is ignored. Ok I forgot, extra Plugins installed:
Planty (Ant Editor Plugin latest version from the net) VeloEdit (same for Velocity) and Jalopy (Sourcecode Formatter)
Machine configuration: Generic Gentoo Linux, with a 2.4.20 CK4 Kernel which has preemtive scheduling and low latency enabled. The system is running on a ReiserFS partition, XFree 4.2.1 GTK 2.2.1/GTK 1.2.10-r9 Processor Athlon TBird 900, 700MB Ram
as for the -Xmx200, thanks for the hint, but didn't solve the problem because it already is like that: here my startup script:
#!/bin/sh cd /home/werpu/development/eclipse ./eclipse -vm /opt/blackdown-j2sdk1.4.1/bin/java -Xmx 200m
Sorry, I just noticed the bug with the blank in -Xmx200m in my startup script, corrected it, but doesn't help with the problem, the memory doesn't really seem to be the issue, my personal guess is some kind of concurrency problem/deadlock I'm running into in the create directory dialog since I run an optimized kernel.
Werner, when it hangs, which processes are consuming CPU? We've seen various hanging problems on GTK 2.1.1, which sometimes show CPU split between the X server and eclipse java vm at about 60%/30%. We haven't done much testing on GTK 2.2 or GTK 2.2.1 since we've been having a hard time actually getting a stable install of it on RedHat 8 or 8.1.

Build 20030317
In self-hosting workspace, I was searching for references to IClasspathEntry#getEntryKind() in jdt/core and was surprised by how long it took given only 58 references are expected.

Bug.Summery: Changes in Java Editor do not propagate to other views.
Bug.WithStack:
I had a type C open in both the Java editor and the type hirarchy.
Focus of the type hirarchy was on some baseclass A.
The type hirarchy showed a sibling class B of C, i.e.,
class B extends A class C extends A
I manually edited the source code of C, in the Java editor, changing it to
class C extends B
, and saved that change.
That structural change did not propagate properly to the type view.
This may or may not be related to bug 35020. Can't be reproduce using the simple A, B, C case. When changing the supertype of C from A to B the type hierarchy updates correctly.
Andreas, can you provide any additional information. Is there something in the log ? Forgot to mention that I used I20030318
Ooops - I should have mentioned, B and C are inner types of some (different) classes.
I use RC2 aka 200303071024. Can't reproduce even if B and C are static inner types of a class D. Any additional hint to reproduce this. Closing, no reponse from reporter and not able to reproduce problem.

Bug.Summery: Missing icons when plugins imported but not copied locally

Lines.Line: 1) Start a fresh workspace
2) Import all plugins in binary form without copied them locally
3) Open org.eclipse.jdt.ui
4) Open the plugin.xml file
5) You can see that some icons are missing.
6) Go to the Extensions tab
7) Expand: org.eclipse.ui.perspectives

Bug.WithStack:
Using 0317 build, when I import existing binary plugins in my workspace without copied them locally, I end up with missing icons in the plugin editor when I open the plugin.xml file (Red square). This is pretty ugly. It looks like the editor is unable to retrieve the icon in a linked folder.
Steps to reproduce: 1) Start a fresh workspace 2) Import all plugins in binary form without copied them locally 3) Open org.eclipse.jdt.ui 4) Open the plugin.xml file 5) You can see that some icons are missing. 6) Go to the Extensions tab 7) Expand: org.eclipse.ui.perspectives
You will find something similar to the next screenshot. Created attachment 4242 Missing icons Trivial to fix.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Using 0317 build, when I import existing binary plugins in my workspace without copied them locally, I end up with missing icons in the plugin editor when I open the plugin.xml file (Red square). This is pretty ugly. It looks like the editor is unable to retrieve the icon in a linked folder.
Steps to reproduce: 1) Start a fresh workspace 2) Import all plugins in binary form without copied them locally 3) Open org.eclipse.jdt.ui 4) Open the plugin.xml file 5) You can see that some icons are missing. 6) Go to the Extensions tab 7) Expand: org.eclipse.ui.perspectives
You will find something similar to the next screenshot. Created attachment 4242 Missing icons Trivial to fix.

Bug.Summery: [CVS Core] deleted managed files are re-created as ignored

Lines.Line: 1. create a new java project.
2. set source folder as 'src' and output as 'bin'.
3. add some packages and classes, build.
4. share project with a CVS repo
5. add and commit all in bin folder (enable CVS decorators)
6. turnoff auto build, delete the project
7. checkout the project from the repo (all files and folders should be managed
at this point)
8. turn on autobuild
9. all the files in 'bin' are unmanged and ignored. This is wrong. They should
still be managed and be outgoing changes.

Bug.WithStack:
1. create a new java project. 2. set source folder as 'src' and output as 'bin'. 3. add some packages and classes, build. 4. share project with a CVS repo 5. add and commit all in bin folder (enable CVS decorators) 6. turnoff auto build, delete the project 7. checkout the project from the repo (all files and folders should be managed at this point) 8. turn on autobuild 9. all the files in 'bin' are unmanged and ignored. This is wrong. They should still be managed and be outgoing changes.
Somehow the phantom information for the deleted files is being lost. The CVS test suites should include a builder for testing build related scenarios. Post 3.0 We do not plan on addressing this issue.
Bug.WithOutStack:
1. create a new java project. 2. set source folder as 'src' and output as 'bin'. 3. add some packages and classes, build. 4. share project with a CVS repo 5. add and commit all in bin folder (enable CVS decorators) 6. turnoff auto build, delete the project 7. checkout the project from the repo (all files and folders should be managed at this point) 8. turn on autobuild 9. all the files in 'bin' are unmanged and ignored. This is wrong. They should still be managed and be outgoing changes.
Somehow the phantom information for the deleted files is being lost. The CVS test suites should include a builder for testing build related scenarios. Post 3.0 We do not plan on addressing this issue.

Bug.Summery: [CVS Core] file deleted tasks not created when parent folder deleted

Lines.Line: 1. delete a file that is managed by CVS -> a CVS deleted task appears in the
task view
2. delete a folder that contains managed files -> no tasks are generated

Bug.WithStack:
2.1 RC3 1. delete a file that is managed by CVS -> a CVS deleted task appears in the task view 2. delete a folder that contains managed files -> no tasks are generated
Tasks should be created if a folder that contains mamnaged files is deleted. This is not critical because sync'ing will correctly show the files as outgoing deletions. There are no tasks anymore
Bug.WithOutStack:
2.1 RC3 1. delete a file that is managed by CVS -> a CVS deleted task appears in the task view 2. delete a folder that contains managed files -> no tasks are generated
Tasks should be created if a folder that contains mamnaged files is deleted. This is not critical because sync'ing will correctly show the files as outgoing deletions. There are no tasks anymore

Bug.Summery: [doc] Property naming in the builder and the packager
Bug.WithStack:
Here is the list of the properties used in the builder and the packager with a brief description.
(xxx) are old name or properties, the new name is given after.
Packager ========
workingDirectory: The directory where all the packaging related files will be generated, unzipped, ... downloadDirectory: The directory where the files will be downloaded tempDirectory: The directory in which the files will be unzipped, and zipped from resultDirectory: The directory where all the results of the packager will be stored (used now)
packagingInfo: The directory in which the file called packager.properties is located packagingProperties: A relative path to the file containing the properties for element to package
contentFilter: a comma separated list of value used to filter the files that are downloaded config: The config for which the packager is running (it is only one config) featureList: A comma separated list of features to package
featurePaths: A comma separated list of paths where features and plugins are located. An entry must point to one level up above the "features" and "plugins" directory (example eclipse)
(collBase) zipBase: The directory from which the zip will be built (collPlace) rootZipDirectory: The directory that will be used as a root in the zip. All the files to be zipped must be under this directory. A typical configuration of those variables is: zipBase=. rootZipDirectory=eclipse
zipArgs: Extra arguments that can be passed to the zip command unzipArgs: Extra arguments that can be passed to the unzip command
Builder ======= mapVersionTag: Version of the map files used buildDirectory: The directory in which the build will happen
(collBase) zipBase: The directory from which the zip will be built (collPlace) rootZipDirectory: The directory that will be used as a root in the zip. All the files to be zipped must be under this directory.
configs: an ampersand separated list of config (each component of a config is separated by a comma)
bootClasspath: The path to a rt.jar javacFailOnError: The value that will be used as a parameter to the failonerror property of the javac ant task javacDebugInfo: The value that will be used as a parameter to the debuginfo property of the javac ant task javacVerbose: The value that will be used as a parameter to the verbose property of the javac ant task
zipArgs: Extra arguments that can be passed to the zip command unzipArgs: Extra arguments that can be passed to the unzip command
baseLocation: An installation of eclipse to compile against baseOs: The Os of the eclipse installed in baseLocation baseWs: The ws of the eclipse installed in baseLocation baseArch: The arch of the eclipse installed in baseLocation
Eclipse specific vars --------------------- buildLabel: buildId: also these vars are now used to in some scripts, they should be replaced by more generic names buildType:
timestamp noMail When doing the replacement/renaming check the case of: baseLocation javacFailOnError baseOS baseWS baseArch bootClasspath
buildId buildLabel buildType
Check the scripts for buildid, buildID, buildId Addition of two new javac properties: javacSource javacTarget
Changing bug assignment to pde-build-inbox. (pde-core-inbox is obsolete) collBase and collPlace have been removed and replaced with archivePrefix and collectingFolder. The semantics of collBase and collPlace changed. *** Bug 42474 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 32242 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** This has been fixed in HEAD. The doc regarding the usage of the pde build in an automated build mode and the packager have not been included because they are subject to change and we already have a stub of an article available. Is the article stub available in cvs? There is a description of the pde builder in the org.eclipse.releng.basebuilder (file called readme I believe). Sonia an I are reworking the text, examples of this document in the pde-build- home project.
No description is available for the packager.

Bug.Summery: OrganizeImports proposes less variants, than manual code assist proposals
Bug.WithStack:
I've got the following code:
for (int i = 0; i < list.getLength(); i++) { Node item = list.item(i); if (item.getNodeType() == Node.ELEMENT_NODE) { result.add(getElementUniqueName((Element) item)); } } return result;
All types except "Element" are resolved. Apply "Organize Imports", there are 3 variants (including e.g. javax.swing.text.Element), but no org.w3c.dom one. On manual code assist (i.e. CTRL-SPACE after "Element"), I'm getting required org.w3c.dom.
There are no clashes in imports.
Eclipse 200303120800. problem confirmed in 0318.
Not a stop ship but annoying. investigate to understand the cause since it is reproducable. com.ibm.rmi.corba.Element is not visible and organize import filters non visible types. Code assist does not filter but should (checkbox in editor preference page 'Show only proposals visible') Martin, AFAIU you're pointing to another problem, which explains why more choices are available in code assist, however I'd like to attract your attention to the fact that in code snapshot there is already imported class org.w3c.dom.Node (like I said all types, except Element, are resolved) and org.w3c.dom.Element is definitely visible in the context. yes, you're right. moving back to jdt.ui
I can't reproduce it in my workspace but erich has it Created attachment 4269 fix The bug is in our all types cache. Method getTypesForName returns not all the types with the given name if the workspace contains several project with the types of the same qualified type name. In the case of such a workspace, organize import would remove imports as it can't find the types
approved by Erich and Philippe revieved by Dirk released

Code assist does not filter but should (checkbox in editor preference page 'Show only proposals visible') Martin, AFAIU you're pointing to another problem, which explains why more choices are available in code assist, however I'd like to attract your attention to the fact that in code snapshot there is already imported class org.w3c.dom.Node (like I said all types, except Element, are resolved) and org.w3c.dom.Element is definitely visible in the context. yes, you're right. moving back to jdt.ui
I can't reproduce it in my workspace but erich has it Created attachment 4269 fix The bug is in our all types cache. Method getTypesForName returns not all the types with the given name if the workspace contains several project with the types of the same qualified type name. In the case of such a workspace, organize import would remove imports as it can't find the types
approved by Erich and Philippe revieved by Dirk released

Bug.Summery: package explorer filters load plugins eagerly
Bug.WithStack:
20030318 maybe it's fine but it seems like package explorer filters load plugins eagerly so, after startup, you have pde.ui and pde.core loaded, you want it or not
not sure if this can be avoided, though Are the plugins also loaded when the filter isn't checked? This is caused by the binary plugin filter. The two plug-ins are only loaded if the filter is active. So there is nothing we can do here.
Bug.WithOutStack:
20030318 maybe it's fine but it seems like package explorer filters load plugins eagerly so, after startup, you have pde.ui and pde.core loaded, you want it or not
not sure if this can be avoided, though Are the plugins also loaded when the filter isn't checked? This is caused by the binary plugin filter. The two plug-ins are only loaded if the filter is active. So there is nothing we can do here.

Bug.Summery: Merging branches
Bug.WithStack:
Hello, We have several pbs with CVS, especially for this bug report for merging branches. We have tried the Merge menu item in the navigator view, but without success. So we tried another way to merge branches ; for instance we want to merge a version X on a branch A onto the Head branch for making a Version Y * we update locally the project_head from server * we update locally the project_branchA version X from the server * we make a comparison to see the changes (just for check) but we want to copy everything from X at the same time * we copy the selected directory from the Version X branch * we paste this directory in the head branch (the directory already exists) !!!This paste operation does copy also CVS information from project X into the branch head; we don't want to copy these information!!! So we try anopther thing ; we export the slected dir on disk to eliminate the CVS repository information, and we try to copy from a windows explorer into the eclipse workbench the files inside the directory...without success
How can we do a clean merging between branches? Start by explaining why the Merge action didn't work? It is not doing what we expected (see the mail), ie it doesn't act as we expected it was...Actually, the merge function is not usable in its form by us (6 engineers in the department)... What mail?
You have to understand that we use the merge action all the time and it works with our use-cases. We would like to understand, very exactly, what isn't working for you. We need steps to reproduce and not just "it isn't working as we expected". the bug report if you prefer. I know it is not obvious to maintain this part of code in eclipse, but we have a user point of view which is not the developper point of view. Personaly, I try to convince people in my team to use eclipse, and especially TeamCVS. Many of my bug, or enhancement reports are only the feeling of my engineers (and me) about some functionalities. It seems to them that it is often quite complicated to achieve their goals, like merging, recovering an old version on the current branch locally without changing the project properties (for instance, if you have locally a branch locally synchronized with the server, and you want to replace your current code by code of another version on the same branch, you use the "replace ..;" menu item. If you do that, and you look at the CVS properties of the project, you see that the branch name as been replaced by the version name, and it is not what we intend to have), seeing the branch tree, having some information about version in the CVS repository view, and so on... Very often to these requirements, I received an answer like : "we can't do that because... Won't fix ", but the needs are still there!!! It seems to me there are techhnical possibilities to achieve these goals : use of the .project file (which should be saved in repositoy or updated from the server automatically), the CVSROOT directory with other added files (like CVSMailer does for instance), and so on... regards Xavier To replace a file in the workbench with the contents of another revision, use the History view. Then select the revision and from the context menu select "Get Contents". This will get the revision contents but not update the base revision of the file in your workbench.
It is unfair to say that we don't want to fix or even consider your enhancement requests. But you have to provide clear, detailed steps to either reproduce or good explanation of the requested feature. We have *tons* of work to do and we can't possibly spend all that time trying to understand vague bugs reports.
I'm closing this one because I have no idea what you are asking. And I think I've answered the main question in the original bug. the question is not to do that on one file, but on a whole directory at the same time

Bug.Summery: Commit decorators
Bug.WithStack: Hello, We have some difficulties with the commit action. We follow the following scheme : * we synchronize the repositories * we commit files from the synchronization view without pb * we look at the committed files in the navigator view, and they are still in changed mode ( decorator >). We have to remake a commit from the Navigator view this time to clean up these decorators... It seems to us , it is not correct. What build? In 2.1 RC3 we have fixed several decorator problems. Please re-open if you can dupe this bug with RC3. RC2
Bug.WithOutStack: Hello, We have some difficulties with the commit action. We follow the following scheme : * we synchronize the repositories * we commit files from the synchronization view without pb * we look at the committed files in the navigator view, and they are still in changed mode ( decorator >). We have to remake a commit from the Navigator view this time to clean up these decorators... It seems to us , it is not correct. What build? In 2.1 RC3 we have fixed several decorator problems. Please re-open if you can dupe this bug with RC3. RC2

Bug.Summery: Plugin import does not detect host dir when running with -dev bin
Bug.WithStack:
build I20030317
From a Sametime transcript with Dejan...
Nick_Edgar@ca... Dejan, I had a strange problem last night on I20030317. I tried reimporting my binary projects, but it pulled them out of an older install (I20030313). (I put each build in a separate dir). The Target Platform pref page was pointing to d:\eclipse-I20030313\eclipse. I could not change it back to "this application" because that radio button was disabled. I the "another compatible application" field to point to d:\eclipse- I20030317\eclipse and tried re-importing, but this time org.eclipse.swt did not find its jar, so there were 1000s of compilation errors. Just upgraded to I20030318. This time the import dialog came up showing d:\eclipse-I20030318, but it had the same problem with import. In the target platform page, "this application" is still disabled. Not sure how it got updated from pointing to d:\eclipse-I20030317 Nick_Edgar@c... to d:\eclipse-I20030318. Nick_Edgar@c... Tried deleting my .config dir, and also any metadata under org.eclipse.pde.core, but this made no difference. Nick_Edgar@c... Switching to a new workspace and reconstructing a self-hosting workspace worked OK. dejan@ca.ibm.c... 'This application' means that we are initializing our model directly from the live registry. We had problems with this optimization in the second Eclipse instance because some of the plug-ins are source plug-ins in the dev workspace (the first instance). That is why we prohibit using 'This application' when in second, third etc. instance (i.e. when BootLoader.isDevelopmentMode returns true). Nick_Edgar@c... I was not running my target. All the above happened in the 1st instance. dejan@ca.ibm.c... The only time when 'This application' is disabled is when 'BootLoader.isDevelopmentMode' is returning true. Are you using '-dev' in your first instance? Nick_Edgar@c... I do launch with -dev bin -update, though dejan@ca.ibm.c... There you go Nick_Edgar@c... Was this a recent change? This always worked fine for me before I20030317. dejan@ca.ibm.c... Yes. dejan@ca.ibm.c... We thought that '-dev' is exclusive to launched (second) instance. Nick_Edgar@c... You should announce this to eclipse-dev. Many others run with - dev bin. Nick_Edgar@c... It's used when you want to run with a patch against your 1st instance. dejan@ca.ibm.c... Ack. dejan@ca.ibm.c... The assumption we make is that all the plug-ins in the registry are binary i.e. have JARs. If that is not the case i.e. if some classes are not packaged in JARs, many PDE operations that depend on it may fail. That is why we wanted to guard from that case. dejan@ca.ibm.c... For example, when you import plug-ins, you expect that they don't contain source. Not finding JARs messes up the whole binary plug-in import. Nick_Edgar@c... Why did it end up treating org.eclipse.swt differently? This sounds similar to the problem with source imports that Andrew reported against RC2. dejan@ca.ibm.c... I don't know. Nick_Edgar@c... I think the old behaviour is preferable, and I would consider the new behaviour to be a regression. I want to run with -dev bin because I want the ability to run with a patch against my host. I'm fine if PDE import does not see the patches, and just imports the jars. As it is now, PDE import does not work at all if I run with -dev bin. dejan@ca.ibm.c... Ack Nick_Edgar@c... I'll capture this discussion in a PR. dejan@ca.ibm.c... Thanks. Nick_Edgar@c... Any idea why it changed the "other application" from I20030317 to I20030318. I would have thought that a manually entered field would not get changed automatically. I thought that was why it was still referring to I20030313. It seems like it is updated sometimes, but not always. dejan@ca.ibm.c... If you manually enter something, it will preserve it. If you never change it, we use the default value and this default value is computed. Nick_Edgar@c... This is not the behaviour I saw. When I noticed I was getting stale plugins when importing on I20030317, the "other application" was set to my I20030313 dir. I manually changed it to my I20030317 dir. When I upgraded to I20030318, "other application" was automatically changed to my I20030318 dir. dejan@ca.ibm.c... OK, it may be a different bug. Nick_Edgar@c... I was unable to reproduce the problem with importing org.eclipse.swt in a new workspace. If I run with or without -dev bin -update, it works OK and includes the jar from org.eclipse.swt.win32. dejan@ca.ibm.c... We may still have a bug, but ellusive :-) Nick_Edgar@c... OK, thanks. I'll file the PR to capture this. To be clear, I consider this to be a regression.
Have checked some of the extra internal core team tests as we do use -dev but not usually on the first Eclipse. Looks like we are okay so far but we do consider this a regression as well. In the strict term, this is reduction in flexibility, but we should pull further back and ask why -dev was added in the first place. It was always there to aid self-hosting i.e. to be used on the launched Eclipse, not on the first instance. The fact that we may be using -dev for what it was not designed for is orthogonal IMHO. Thanks for the notice on eclipse-dev. And, yes, I for one sometimes need to run with -dev bin. Plus, sounds like this change would effect all "down stream" products, such as WSAD ... and I would guess that the further downstream you go, the higher the probability that someone somewhere sometime has to run with -dev bin, to make use of some fix, usually to get around a "show stopping" problem until official fix comes out. While hopefully would never be common-place, to never have it at all seems a big (new) limitation. I confess I didn't quite follow all the reasons (pros and cons) for the change, in the IM chat exchange, but just wanted to make this point about "down stream" products (and their developers) being effected too.
Oh, but maybe I misunderstand. Dejan, in your last comment, you say "intended to be used for self hosting, on the launched eclipse, not on first instance" I was assuming 'first instance' was the launched eclipse. In either case, my main concern is with the self-hosting situation, during the development of other downstream products ... so that case still works? I use -dev bin in my outer (1st) eclipse a lot to run with and test fixes in my live development environment. I don't think it should be used to differentiate between running an outer vs. inner Eclipse. The "Running Eclipse" doc does not mention any restrictions for using this option. I did not notice a problem with plugin import because I rename my eclipse directory before unzipping a new build.
DJ confirmed that plug-ins can access command line arguments.
Using this capability, PDE workbench launcher can pass a command line argument that only PDE understands (for example, -launched or something). We would do the same as today, but instead of checking 'BootLoader.isDevelopmentMode()', we would check for presence of the command line argument. This would effectively remove the regression in the first instance (we would not disable 'this application' even if -dev was used).
Does anybody have objections to the proposed solution? If you agree in principal, do you have suggestions for the actual argument name (to minimise name collisions)? -pdelaunch?
Something like that. Fixed.
PDE launcher will from now on be passing -pdelaunch command line argument to the instance it is launching. PDECore class is now checking for the argument in its constructor and sets the flag. We added PDECore.inLaunchedInstance() method to use elsewhere in PDE whenever we need to do something differently in this mode.
We will not be affected by -dev usage any more.
Did this actually make it into the RC3 rebuild (I20030319)? From the timing of messages on the eclipse-dev list it looks like it, but can you confirm?
It did. I just downloaded RC3 candidate and confirmed that this fix is in.

Bug.Summery: Rename Java-template dialog message is wrong
Bug.WithStack:
When renaming a java-template in RC2 a message dialog is shown. It says: 'The name of the template has changed.' That's right but the dialog has Yes/No buttons. If you hit yes a new template is created according to the changes if you hit no the old one is changed. I think the message is misleading and should be a question or something.
It's not a major bug but I was a bit confused so it should change ;) Moving to JDT/UI for comment. Agreed the message should be replace/create
not critical enough for 2.1 Reopening... fixed some time ago.
